assessments.task_description:
Group presentation 40% (10 minutes plus approximately 5 minutes Q&A)

By Day Three, you will form a small group (3-5 students). You will be given opportunities for group formation during the seminars on Day Three, and you may choose your own members. 

Your final assessment task will be a group presentation.

Topic choice

Your group will choose a topic from a list of provided topics. During the seminars we will discuss current laws, but also note areas where the law is inadequate, or is failing to address relevant issues. We will also discuss current and emerging areas of law reform. This task gives you the opportunity to choose an area of law, conduct research, and present your ideas as to how the law could achieve better outcomes for clients and society.

You are encouraged to discuss your proposed topic with the course staff.

Due date

The group presentation will take place on Saturday 14 February 2026.

In class, you will be shown how to book a session for your group presentation.

Format

Each oral presentation session will be 3 hours, to allow up to 10 to 12 groups to present. All group members must be present for the session. Your group will be presenting to the course coordinator and a small group of fellow students.

You may use a single page handout to support your in-person presentation. Powerpoint presentations are not allowed.

Group input

All group members must contribute to selecting, developing, researching, and presenting the topic. The oral component of the presentation may be given by a single group member or some/all of the members. However, all group members must be prepared to answer questions during the Q&A component. Every group member will receive the same mark, unless a case is made otherwise. Two assessors will review the presentation (in-person or a recording) to provide moderation of grades.

Resources to support your group work will be provided on the course BlackBoard and discussed in class.

assessments.task_description:
A choice of research questions will be given, in relation to current issues in the international legal profession. Students will be required to prepare a research paper on a topic selected from those questions.

The word limit for the essay is a maximum of 2,200 words, and any material beyond that will not be read. By way of clariﬁcation, this word count:

  • includes headings;
  • does not include text in the header or word count; and
  • does not include footnotes - however footnotes should be used for citation purposes only. Any substantive text that appears in the footnote will not be read and will not contribute to your mark.

For style and referencing, students should refer to the Australian Guide to Legal Citation.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

Usage of AI is allowed in this assessment piece, but must be done within the indications and constraints indicated on Blackboard at the beginning of the course. These include (typically in the assessment appendix) the prompts utilised to query AI, the responses provided by the AI, and evidence of critical analysis of text-generated AI, before usage in the assessment. Moreover, usage of AI needs to be adequately referenced in the assessment. These guidelines are provided because, to pass this assessment, student will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written independent of AI tools.

A failure to use AI according to the guidelines above (and detailed on Blackboard at the beginning of the course) may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.

learning_activities.topic:
What is a lawyer?

This introductory section examines the concept of the lawyer as a legal professional within contemporary Australian and comparative contexts. It explores the historical evolution of the legal profession, the institutional structures that shape legal practice, and the regulatory frameworks governing admission, professional conduct, and accountability. Attention is given to the multiple roles lawyers occupy—as advocates, advisers, officers of the court, and participants in the administration of justice—and to how these roles are shaped by ethical obligations, professional norms, and public expectations.

The section also critically engages with competing theoretical perspectives on lawyering, including conceptions of the lawyer as a neutral technician, a moral agent, and a social actor with responsibilities extending beyond client service. It invites students to reflect on questions of professional identity, independence, and power, as well as the lawyer’s role in advancing access to justice, the rule of law, and the public interest. Through this inquiry, students are encouraged to situate their own professional aspirations within a broader understanding of what it means to be a lawyer in a complex, pluralistic, and evolving legal environment.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Globalisation of the Profession

This section considers that global aspects of the legal profession. We will consider the roles of lawyers working in an international context such as lawyers working:

  • in a large international law firm,
  • in-house in an international corporate legal department,
  • for government,
  • for an international charity, and
  • for an international human rights or international non-government organisation.



Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
International Law Firm Legal and Organisational Structures

We will examine the organisational structures of international law firms, the benefits and disadvantages of each structure, and how these structures impact lawyer behaviour. For example we will consider:

  • Swiss Verein structures
  • Global "one firm" structures
  • Partnerships of partnerships
  • Corporate structures
  • Strategic Alliances
  • Marketing networks

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Economics of Law firms and impact on lawyer behaviour

This section will consider the law firm as a business, how law firms make profits, and how profits are distributed. We will review the "eat what you kill" and lockstep partner compensation models. We will examine what PPEP and RPEP, how these are calculated, and what impact this has on lawyer behaviour.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
The Digital Lawyer - Impact of technology – alternative models for the delivery of legal services

This section considers how new technologies, such as AI and digital legal services, and new business models, such as legal process outsourcing and globalised service delivery, will impact the practice of law in an international environment.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
The legal assistance sector - community legal services, legal aid, civil society, and pro bono legal services

This section examines the legal assistance sector encompassing community legal centres, legal aid commissions, civil society organisations, and pro bono legal services. It explores the institutional roles, funding arrangements, and regulatory frameworks that shape the delivery of legal assistance to individuals and communities experiencing disadvantage. Particular attention is given to the interaction between state-funded services, non-profit and community-based providers, and the private legal profession, as well as the systemic pressures created by unmet legal need, resource constraints, and growing demand for legal support.

The section also critically analyses the contribution of the legal assistance sector to access to justice, law reform, and the protection of rights. Students are encouraged to consider the ethical, professional, and policy dimensions of legal assistance work, including prioritisation of services, collaboration across sectors, and the role of pro bono practice within a broader justice ecosystem. Through engagement with contemporary challenges and reform debates, the section situates the legal assistance sector within wider discussions about the social responsibilities of lawyers, the rule of law, and the capacity of legal institutions to respond to inequality and structural injustice.

Learning outcomes: L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Human rights and human rights defenders

This section introduces international human rights law as a normative and institutional framework governing the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms at the global and regional levels. It examines the sources of international human rights law, including treaties, customary international law, and soft law instruments, and the roles of key actors such as the United Nations, regional human rights bodies, states, and non-state actors. The section situates international human rights norms within broader political, cultural, and legal contexts, and considers the relationship between international human rights obligations and domestic legal systems, including Australia’s engagement with international human rights mechanisms.

The section also focuses on the role of human rights defenders in advancing, monitoring, and enforcing human rights in diverse international settings. It explores the legal protections afforded to human rights defenders, the risks and challenges they face—including repression, criminalisation, and violence—and the responsibilities of states and international institutions to ensure their safety and effectiveness. Students are encouraged to critically engage with contemporary case studies and debates, reflecting on the ethical responsibilities of lawyers, advocates, and civil society actors in supporting human rights work and responding to violations in an increasingly complex and contested global environment.

Learning outcomes: L02, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Cultural Intelligence in Legal Practice

This section introduces cultural intelligence as a core professional capability in contemporary legal practice. It examines how culture shapes legal institutions, communication, decision-making, and client–lawyer relationships, with particular attention to Australia’s multicultural society and its engagement with Indigenous peoples and diverse global legal systems. The section highlights the impact of cultural assumptions and power dynamics on legal processes and outcomes, and the importance of culturally responsive and reflective lawyering.

The section also develops practical and ethical dimensions of cultural intelligence, including cross-cultural communication, professional judgment, and collaborative practice in domestic and international legal contexts. Students are encouraged to critically reflect on their own positionality and professional responsibilities, and to consider how culturally informed legal practice contributes to fairness, access to justice, and effective legal service delivery in an increasingly interconnected legal environment.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

We will examine in this section the regulations that impact the practice of law in various jurisdictions, including how government regulation impacts the practice of law across international boundries and the establishment of global law firm. Ethical issues will also be considered and discussed.
